title: What do colleges do to assist their students' mental health? - Quora

response.answer_text: Almost every college has a mental health clinic comprised of psychologists, social workers, and mental health counselors; those very small colleges will still have professionals outside of the college that are “contracted” with the school to see students. Many students do not even know their college has these free services. Unfortunately, they aren’t “advertised” much on campus. These clinics also are where clinical and school psychology grad students fulfill their training requirements. As such, if you go to your college’s clinic, you may either get a licensed professional or a trainee. The trainees are usually very eager and well-supported by their supervisors, so I wouldn’t be so uninclined to see one if I were a student in need of help.

Generally, not enough. When I was in college, I went once to a psychologist at the student health center. I didn’t like her much. When my elder child went to college, he had a long history of needing regular therapy. They only had short term therapy and a possible support group. He would have had to go off campus to get regular therapy, which he wasn’t willing to do. It wasn’t very satisfactory.
